item.title: Betty Reid Soskin, the Eldest National Park Ranger, Leaves a Legacy in the Wake of Her Passing
item.description:
Yesterday, December 22, 2025, Betty Reid Soskin died, her death confirmed by her son, Bob Reid. And while her most recent claim to fame is her decision to join the National Park service as a park ranger at 85 (retiring at the ripe old age of 100), Betty was, as she self-proclaimed, “an absolutely ordinary extraordinary person.” Sauce: https://apnews.com/article/national-park-rosie-riveter-soskin-ranger-ccf760e3cd47449ba1c9f2093c186a80 (my apologies, this took longer to compile than I thought it would, so it's a day late)
(Photo credit: Boilermakers Union, Local Auxiliary 36 by photographer E.F. Joseph) But that service? It was the last in a lifetime of historical moments that Betty would fight to keep uncovered and alive in the public eye. “I knew my slave ancestor, my great grandmother, until she died at the age of 102, when I was 27 years old,” Reid Soskin says. “All of American history, from the Dred Scott Decision to Black Lives Matter, is encapsulated in the voices of my great grandmother, my mother and myself because we lived all of that history from 1846 to the present time.” ***** During WWII, she worked as a file clerk with the Boilermakers Local Auxiliary 36, a segregated union, at the Kaiser Shipyards along thousands of other women who helped construct 700 Liberty & Victory ships. Part of the well-known "Rosie the Riveter" story, the contribution of black women was omitted, not even considered part of that movement until 1944 when some of them were taught welding. While she and her fellow Black workers would receive an apology from the union in 2016--"an apology for what must have been a demeaning life experience"--that did nothing to make up for the suffering they endured. This would lead to her park ranger position, where she shared her experience with visitors to the Rosie the Riveter WWII Home Front National Historical Park in RIchmond, California. She wasn't just the park ranger there. She also helped plan the park during her time working as a state legislative aide, which allowed her to ensure the inclusion of contributions of black women and men. Rosie the Riveter WWII Home Front National Historical Park: https://www.nps.gov/rori/index.htm Betty Reid Soskin Rosie the Riveter World War II American Homefront Oral History Project: https://digitalassets.lib.berkeley.edu/roho/ucb/text/Soskin.pdf
(photo courtesy of the Betty Reid Soskin) In 1945, she and her first husband opened Reid's Records on Sacramento Street in West Berkeley, CA, one of the first black-owned record stores in the area. During the Civil Rights era, she was a bridge between her liberal white community and the Black Panthers, collecting money in the suburbs around Diablo Valley, holding fundraisers, and delivering all the donations to Kathleen and Eldridge Cleaver. The first black family to live in the white suburb of Walnut Creek was met with upset and threats, including a burning cross on the front lawn. But the same community elected her 20 years later to serve as their delegate to the 1972 DNC. “That is how fast social change occurred,” she said. In the 70s, while reviving Reid's Records, she fought Berkeley's City Hall to clean up the drug corridor on Sacramento Street. Her efforts were so effective, she would eventually end up as the legislative aide to Berkeley council member Don Jelinek. Working with then-Berkeley mayor Gus Newport, she helped build low-income housing throughout the city, by lobbying for the purchase and renovation of some of the existing crack houses, a project that would eventually be called Rumford Plaza. Additional servings of sauce: A History of Reid's Records: https://geoffreyslive.com/acknowledging/a-history-of-reids-records/ Betty Soskin: A living monument to WWII history (2015) https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/federal_government/betty-soskin-a-living-monument-to-wwii-history/2015/06/12/09b2ae90-1144-11e5-9726-49d6fa26a8c6_story.html
In the aftermath of her divorce, she was raising her children in a society continuing to be impacted by segregation and racism. To survive this trying time, she found solace in singing, but she kept it to herself. “I packed ‘secret Betty’ up in boxes in reel-to-reel tapes. No one in my life knew that I had been a singer or that I had written music,” Reid Soskin says in the trailer of Brian Gibel’s film, tentatively titled Sign My Name to Freedom: The Lost Music of Betty Reid Soskin. Reid-Soskin said, “I was documenting all of the events that we were experiencing as a country and that I was experiencing in isolation, in songs. Maybe releasing the music to the public is a way of making myself whole. And maybe I need to do that before I die.” Her granddaughter, Alyana Reid, said that one of her songs, “Your Hand in Mine,” is a cornerstone of the film and an example of an act of resistance. “My grandma describes it as a hand-holding song to take the place of ‘We Shall Overcome,’ which was taken from the civil rights movement and misused by Lyndon B. Johnson.” The documentary, currently in post-production, is still seeking tax-deductible donations to assist with its release in 2026. Donation link: https://signmynametofreedom.allyrafundraising.com/ Even more sauce: Betty Reid Soskin: The Musical https://eastbayexpress.com/betty-reid-soskin-the-musical/ Audio Interview with her daughter, Diara Melite Kitty Reid https://www.kalw.org/2024-02-20/the-music-of-betty-reid-soskin
FREEDOM SONGS Betty (bottom center) and the cast of ‘Sign My Name to Freedom: The Unheard Songs of Betty Reid Soskin.’ (Photo by Alexa Trevino) In 2024, the San Francisco Bay Area Theater Company turned her story into a musical called, "Sign My Name To Freedom: The Unheard Songs of Betty Reid Soskin", written by Michael Gene Sullivan, conceptualized by Jamie Zimmer and directed by Elizabeth Carter. It ran from March 28- April 13th. Sauce: https://eastbayexpress.com/betty-reid-soskin-the-musical/
“Betty Reid Soskin took the path we mistakenly assign to Rosa Parks,” Allen-Taylor noted in his editor’s note. “Betty rarely chose her life’s battles in advance, as Rosa did. Instead, she faced them as they came — working, raising a family, choosing a home, operating a business on her own. Her sign-ups for the freedom fights were generally unplanned and spontaneous, and in that, she showed all of us what ordinary citizens facing up to their fears can accomplish.” And after all those fights, despite the very dark times we are living in, Soskin is optimistic. “At this point,” she said, “I see democracy as something that will never be ‘fixed.’ It’s a process, and every generation has to recreate it in its time or die. It’s a kind of upward spiral: each time we hit those places at higher and higher levels, setting the patterns for the next generation.” “Looking at it that way gives me hope,” Soskin said. “We are in a period of regression right now, but the way out, I think, will become visible.” You can read more about her extraordinary life in her memoir, "Sign My Name to Freedom." Buy it here: https://www.signmynamebook.com/ Elevensies of Sauce: Women's History Month: An Interview with 93 year old National Park Service Ranger Betty Reid Soskin (lots of interesting pictures!) https://www.doi.gov/employees/news/womens-history-month-an-interview-with-93-year-old-national-park-service-ranger-betty-reid-soskin Betty Reid Soskin: The extraordinary life of the nation's oldest park ranger: https://www.berkeleyside.org/2018/02/07/berkeleys-betty-reid-soskin-extraordinary-life-nations-oldest-park-ranger Press Articles from the Documentary Website: https://www.signmynametofreedom.com/press Her blog: https://cbreaux.blogspot.com/

item.title: Another Russian region suffers an economic collapse - as Putin went on record saying the Russian economy is surviving.
item.description: The authorities of Kuzbass announced the region's financial collapse In response to the outrage over the reduction of benefits, the governor of the Kemerovo region, Ilya Seredyuk, recalled that the region is experiencing a difficult economic situation amid a crisis in the coal industry. “The situation in the region is so difficult that we currently have unpaid debts for already built schools, for completed capital repairs of institutions where our children study, for the improvement of territories. Just for today, the outstanding debt that we have already overdue is 4 billion rubles,” he said. According to the governor, the region also has debts for the supply of heat, water and electricity to resource-supplying organizations, which will amount to 4.6 billion rubles by the end of the year.
item.dc:creator: vladrichdemaclant

item.title: A pose a day: Winged, walking magic, spell casting pose
item.description: Hi! I'm AdorkaStock. I photograph myself and others in various poses for art reference. My goal is to include in my galleries of stock poses a variety of body types, skin types, and people doing various things so there is a piece of stock for everyone. I want to share my stock, which is free to use for reference, with as many people as possible in case they need it! FAQ is in my bio. Links list if you want to get off this hell site but continue following me: https://www.adorkastock.com/hub Hope the pose helps you! Happy drawing! #Art #AdorkaStock #Reference #Artist
item.dc:creator: adorkastock
